usersAndGroups.title: Create Policy for Users and Groups

gettingStart.content1: The PolicyView application enables you to create Quality of Service policies that specify for network traffic. Policy rules are stored in a Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP) repository that is automatically installed with the PolicyView application and resides on the same device as the OmniVista Server. QoS-qualified devices in the network are notified when new or modified Policy rules are available on the LDAP repository via an SNMP interface. Software resident in the switch is responsible for retrieving the Policy rules from the LDAP repository, interpreting the Policy rules, and enforcing them on the switch.
gettingStart.content2: When you first open the PolicyView application, the One Touch, Expert, Resource, Resource Group, Policy List, and View tabs are displayed. Any existing devices that are configured for one touch voice mode are displayed.

gettingStart.title: Getting Started with Groups
gettingStart.content1: The Groups application enables you to create groups, which can be used in various policy conditions of PolicyView QoS policies. Groups are stored on an LDAP (Lightweight Directory Access Protocol) repository that is automatically installed with the Groups application and resides on the same device as the OmniVista server. When the switches in the network are notified to re-cache their policy information, the firmware loads the groups referred by these policies.
gettingStart.content2: When you first start the Groups application, the L2 MAC Groups, the L2 VLAN Groups, the L3 Network (IP) Groups, the L3 Multicast (IP) Groups, and the L4 Service Groups tabs are displayed. Any existing MAC groups are displayed in the L2 MAC Groups tab.

workflow.commonGuideline:
You are entering the "__taskName__" task.
Some steps you will do:
  • Select Auth. Servers to authenticate users.
  • Select some roles to use in case Auth. Server return a role name.
  • Select classification rules if no matching role name returned.
  • Select Pass Alternate Role If all of methods above not matched.
  • Select default/Initial role.
To be easy, we create a checklist for you. You can follow step-by-step in that checklist and reach the purpose.
workflow.workflow1Guideline:
You are entering the "__taskName__" configuration workflow.
Configuration consists of the following steps:
  • Select port type to place traffic on the appropriate bridging domain.
  • Select devices and ports to which end user devices are connected.
  • Select Classification Rules with criteria (MAC Address, IP Address, etc.) that will be matched, and the Access Role for the switch to determine how to classify traffic.
  • Select default/initial Access Role if none of the rules can be matched.
Click on "Begin Now" and follow the workflow steps to complete the configuration.
workflow.workflow2Guideline:
You are entering the "__taskName__" configuration workflow.
Configuration consists of the following steps:
  • Select port type to place traffic on the appropriate bridging domain.
  • Select devices and ports to which end user devices are connected.
  • Select a WLAN for wireless devices to which end stations are connected.
  • Select Authentication Servers for devices to contact to authenticate and query user roles.
  • Select Accounting Servers to record authentication sessions.
  • Select Access Roles on the devices to match role names returned by Radius Servers upon successful authentication.
  • Select Classification Rules with criteria (MAC Address, IP Address, etc.) to apply if Radius Servers return no role or users fail authentication.
  • Select Pass Alternate Role to apply if user authentication passes but no match resulted from classification.
  • Select default/initial role if users fail authentication, or both authentication and classification fail to match users to any role.
Click on "Begin Now" and follow the workflow steps to complete the configuration. Apply the configuration after completing the workflow steps.
workflow.workflow3Guideline:
You are entering the "__taskName__" configuration workflow.
Configuration consists of the following steps:
  • Select port type to place traffic on the appropriate bridging domain.
  • Select devices and ports to which end user devices are connected.
  • Select a WLAN for wireless devices to which end stations are connected.
  • Select Authentication Servers for devices to contact to authenticate and query user roles.
  • Select Accounting Servers to record authentication sessions.
  • Select Access Roles on the devices to match role names returned by Radius Servers upon successful authentication.
  • Select Classification Rules with criteria (MAC Address, IP Address, etc.) to apply if Radius Servers return no role or users fail authentication.
  • Select Pass Alternate Role to apply if user authentication passes but no match resulted from classification.
  • Select default/initial role if users fail authentication, or both authentication and classification fail to match users to any role.
Click on "Begin Now" and follow the workflow steps to complete the configuration. Apply the configuration after completing the workflow steps.
workflow.workflow4Guideline:
You are entering the "__taskName__" configuration workflow.
Configuration consists of the following steps:
  • Select port type to place traffic on the appropriate bridging domain.
  • Select devices and ports to which end user devices are connected.
  • Select Authentication Servers for devices to contact to authenticate and query user roles.
  • Select Accounting Servers to record authentication sessions.
  • Select Access Roles on the devices to match role names returned by Radius Servers upon successful authentication.
  • Select a Captive Portal Profile to allow users who fail MAC authentication temporary access for web authentication.
  • Select Classification Rules with criteria (MAC Address, IP Address, etc.) to apply if Radius Servers return no role or users fail authentication.
  • Select Pass Alternate Role to apply if user authentication passes but no match resulted from classification.
  • Select default/initial role if users fail authentication, or both authentication and classification fail to match users to any role.
Click on "Begin Now" and follow the workflow steps to complete the configuration. Apply the configuration after completing the workflow steps.
workflow.workflow5Guideline:
You are entering the "__taskName__" configuration workflow.
Configuration consists of the following steps:
  • Select port type to place traffic on the appropriate bridging domain.
  • Select devices and ports to which end user devices are connected.
  • Select ClearPass Server that devices can contact to authenticate and query user roles.
  • Select Access Roles to send to devices and Clearpass to handle traffic classification upon successful authentication.
  • Select a Captive Portal Role with a specified URL so Clearpass can send CoA messages to devices to redirect users for web authentication.
  • Select Classification rules with criteria (MAC Address, IP Address, etc.) which applies if ClearPass servers return no role or users fail authentication.
  • Select Pass Alternate Role to apply if user authentication passes but no match resulted from classification.
  • Select default/initial role if users fail authentication or both authentication and classification fail to match users to any role.
Click on "Begin Now" and follow the workflow steps to complete the configuration. Apply the configuration after completing the workflow steps.
Note: OmniVista only pairs devices with ClearPass for trust and configuration of Access Roles on both ends. Additional configuration must be done in Clearpass to return the correct Access Role and to provide web-based authentication.

description.content:
To support SNMPv3 with AES 192 and 256, you need to use Zulu Cryptography Extension Kit (CEK)

Please follow these steps to apply Zulu CEK:

  1. You must read and agree to the Terms of Use, and by using this extension you must assent to all Zulu terms as set forth in the Zulu Cryptography Extension Kit (CEK).
  2. Download the Zulu CEK, and carefully review the supplied README.txt, LICENSE and DISCLAIMER files.
  3. Upload all the downloaded *.jar files into OV platform using the form below.

lay1.title: 1 Column (Responsive)
lay1.desc:
This is the layout that has only one column but every widget has the same indicated width and height, and they appear from left to right. It's a quite special. This will show the widgets depending on the width of screen.
If the browser screen has width =1200px, there will be 4 widgets maximum in a row.
If the browser screen has width =992px, there will be 3 widgets maximum in a row.
If the browser screen has width =768px, there will be 2 widgets maximum in a row.
If the browser screen has width <768px, there will be 1 widget maximum in a row.

lay2.title: 1 Column
lay2.desc: This is the layout that has only one column and stretches to full width of screen even when you resize the width of browser screen.

lay3.title: 2 Columns (50% 50%)
lay3.desc: This is the layout that has two columns and stretches to full width of screen even when you resize the width of browser screen. The scale of two columns arranged by order is 50 50.

lay4.title: 2 Columns (70% 30%)
lay4.desc: This is the layout that has two columns and stretches to full width of screen even when you resize the width of browser screen. The scale of two columns arranged by order is 70 30.

lay5.title: 2 Columns (30% 70%)
lay5.desc: This is the layout that has two columns and stretches to full width of screen even when you resize the width of browser screen. The scale of two columns arranged by order is 30 70.

lay6.title: 3 Columns (30% 40% 30%)
lay6.desc: This is the layout that has three columns and stretches to full width of screen even when you resize the width of browser screen. The scale of three columns arranged by order is 30 40 30.

lay7.title: 4 Columns (25% 25% 25% 25%)
lay7.desc: This is the layout that has four columns and stretches to full width of screen even when you resize the width of browser screen. The scale of three columns arranged by order is 25 25 25 25.

lay8.title: Layout (Auto)
lay8.desc:
This is a special layout. This new layout can automatically calculate appropriate width for all widgets in the dashboard based on a hinted width. This means no matter what screen size, the layout will try to figure out the best width of a widget to fit the screen width, thus eliminating any weird empty space.
E.g. on 1024px width screen size, with 5 widgets on the screen, the hinted width for each widget is 300px, and the gutter (spaces between 2 widgets) is 30px, each widget will be given 311.3333 px, and there will be 3 widgets on the first row and 2 widgets on the second row.

form.acceptedLegalStatement: I acknowledge that there are legal issues for using encryption algorithm over 128 bits

legalAndInstructionDlg.title: CEK Legal and Required Action
legalAndInstructionDlg.legalContent:
Some countries have import control restrictions on encryption strength and that's the reason the default encryption policies are restricted to 128 bits. To understand more about these, please read the following articles:

  • Wassenaar Arrangement
  • Patent
  • Search and seizure
  • List of Countries with their import/export restrictions details and explanation
legalAndInstructionDlg.instructionForUser: Please contact system administrator to install Zulu CEK
legalAndInstructionDlg.instructionForAdmin:
To support SNMPv3 with AES 192 and 256, you need to use Zulu Cryptography Extension Kit (CEK)

Please follow these steps to apply Zulu CEK:

  1. Read through its Terms of Use.
  2. Download the Zulu CEK and review the supplied README.txt file to understand how to apply it.
  3. Go to Preferences > System Settings > Install Zulu CEK to upload all the downloaded *.jar files into OV platform (required Account Admin role)
